instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Rabbit hole
threads.message:
First off, completely dead board (another thread).
Got the board starting but fan spins constantly with no light on USB mouse.
No CPU VCORE and <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> at 0.2V.
Found a short on <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> and replaced it. Now i have <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> But still no CPU VCORE

Found that <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> was missing so I replaced <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and I have now got 3,8V there.

Still no CPU VCORE, Pin 20 and 22 on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> gives me nothing.

Should I just replace <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> or look elsewhere?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Rabbit hole
threads.message:
An update, the missing CPU VCORE seems to be my fault, poor <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> soldering, have now got 1V on pin 20 and 22 on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and I have got CPU VCORE.
Fan still spins constantly and no light on USB mouse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Rabbit hole
threads.message: Hmm, CPU VCORE Missing again so probably something else :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Rabbit hole
threads.message:
My god, now <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is missing again. It seems like I jumped to a conclusion a little to fast. It seems like CPU VCORE and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> comes and goes.
Anyone got any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Rabbit hole
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is going to come from <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> working. If they are all present then look carefully for corrosion in the <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> area. This board and the measurements you're giving sound like a ping pong ball you're holding down in water with one finger though so I don't have high hopes here.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Rabbit hole
threads.message: So it is power cycling. The usual shit: <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and termination resistors/traces, <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Rabbit hole
threads.message: No it is not power cycling, when I do get CPU VCORE and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> they stay high but I get no boot, only fan spin. I have replaced <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and tried with another <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>. All resistors look good but maybe a bad capacitor or something. I'll check <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Rabbit hole
threads.message: <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> looked fine but I replaced it anyway, unfortunately it's the same :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Rabbit hole
threads.message: Put back original <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>. Besides that it will probably corrosion under the SMC or some other rabbit hole...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Rabbit hole
threads.message: I have already put back the original <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> since it didn't make any difference, I guess I'll try an SMC reflow first and then replace or re-ball.
